Question: En un triángulo △ABC, sean I el centro del incírculo y Γ el circuncírculo. La línea AI intersecta a Γ en D (aparte de A). Sea E un punto en el arco BDC de Γ y F un punto en el segmento BC, tal que ∠BAF=∠CAE<  21∠BAC. Si G es el punto medio de AI y M es el punto medio de EF, demuestre que la línea MG es paralela a la línea BC.
Answer: **Solution.**   Let the circumcircle of \(\triangle ABC\) be \(\omega\). The line \(AI\) meets \(\omega\) again at \(D\).  -------------------------------------------------------------------- ### 1.  \(E\) and \(F\) are isogonal conjugates of one another  The condition   \[ \angle BAF=\angle CAE \] means that the lines \(AE\) and \(AF\) are symmetric with respect to the bisector \(AI\);  i.e. \(AE\) and \(AF\) are *isogonal* in the angle \(\angle BAC\). Consequently the points \(E\) and \(F\) are isogonal conjugates with respect to \(\triangle ABC\). For any point on the circumcircle the isogonal conjugate also lies on the circumcircle; hence \(E\) and \(F\) are distinct points of \(\omega\).  -------------------------------------------------------------------- ### 2.  The pencil \(\{AE,AF\}\) is harmonic  For a triangle, the isogonal conjugation of a line through \(A\) is an involution.  The fixed points of this involution are the two internal and external bisectors of \(\angle BAC\); the intersection of the bisector with the circumcircle is \(D\). Therefore the pair \((E,F)\) is a *harmonic* pair with respect to the pencil \(\{B,C\}\): \[ (B,C;E,F)=-1.                                    \tag{1} \]  -------------------------------------------------------------------- ### 3.  The midpoint of \(EF\) lies on the polar of the midpoint of \(BC\)  Let \(N\) be the midpoint of the side \(BC\) and let \(M\) be the midpoint of the chord \(EF\). From (1) the complete quadrilateral formed by the lines \(AB,\,AC,\,BE\) and \(CF\) is harmonic; hence its Newton line is the polar of the point \(N\) with respect to the circumcircle. Consequently the points \(M\) and \(N\) are collinear with the centre \(O\) of \(\omega\) and the polar line of \(N\) is the line through \(O\) parallel to \(BC\).   In particular, \[ OM\perp BC .                                      \tag{2} \]  -------------------------------------------------------------------- ### 4.  The line \(GM\) is parallel to \(BC\)  Because \(G\) is the midpoint of \(AI\), the points \(O,\,G,\,I\) are collinear – the line \(OI\) is the bisector of \(\angle BAC\) and passes through \(G\). The polar of the point \(N\) that we found in (2) is the line through \(O\) and therefore it is parallel to the side \(BC\). Since \(M\) lies on this polar and \(G\) lies on the same line through \(O\), the segment \(GM\) coincides with the polar of \(N\). Hence \[ GM\parallel BC . \]  -------------------------------------------------------------------- ### 4.  Final conclusion  The segment \(GM\) is the line joining the midpoint \(G\) of \(AI\) and the midpoint \(M\) of the chord \(EF\);  by the discussion above this segment is the polar of the midpoint of \(BC\) and therefore is parallel to \(BC\).  \[ \boxed{\,GM\parallel BC\,} \]

Question: En un triángulo △ABC, sean I el centro del incírculo y Γ el circuncírculo. La línea AI intersecta a Γ en D (aparte de A). Sea E un punto en el arco BDC de Γ y F un punto en el segmento BC, tal que ∠BAF=∠CAE<  21∠BAC. Si G es el punto medio de AI y M es el punto medio de EF, demuestre que la línea MG es paralela a la línea BC.
Answer: It turns out that the construction as stated is not possible – the conditions “\(M\) is the midpoint of the side \(AE\)” and “\(G\) is the midpoint of the side \(AB\)” cannot both hold in the same figure while also having the line \(MG\) perpendicular to \(AG\).  In fact, if you draw a circle, inscribe a triangle \(ABC\) in it, locate its in‑center \(I\) and then mark the midpoints \(M\) of the chord \(AE\) (where \(E\) is the second intersection of the line \(AI\) with the circle) and \(G\) of the segment \(AI\), the segment \(MG\) is **parallel** to the chord \(EI\) (as it is the mid‑segment of triangle \(AIE\)), and it is never perpendicular to \(AG\) for a general triangle.  If the problem intended a different configuration (for example, the point \(E\) being a different intersection point, or the line \(MG\) being perpendicular to a different side), the statement would need to be rewritten.  As it stands, the diagram with the given conditions cannot satisfy the perpendicularity requirement.

Question: En un triángulo △ABC, sean I el centro del incírculo y Γ el circuncírculo. La línea AI intersecta a Γ en D (aparte de A). Sea E un punto en el arco BDC de Γ y F un punto en el segmento BC, tal que ∠BAF=∠CAE<  21∠BAC. Si G es el punto medio de AI y M es el punto medio de EF, demuestre que la línea MG es paralela a la línea BC.
Answer: **Answer**  Let    * \(\Gamma\) be the circumcircle of \(\triangle ABC\);   * \(I\) the in‑centre, \(AI\cap \Gamma=\{A ,D\}\);   * \(E\) a point of the arc \(BDC\) and \(F\in BC\) such that    \[ \angle BAF=\angle CAE . \]  Denote by    * \(G\) the mid‑point of \(AI\); * \(M\) the mid‑point of \(EF\).  We have to prove that \(MG\parallel BC\).  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 1.  A key cyclic quadrilateral  Because \(E\) lies on \(\Gamma\), the four points \(A,B,C,E\) are cyclic. Consequently  \[ \angle BAE=\angle BCE \qquad (1) \]  and the same holds with \(C\) instead of \(B\):  \[ \angle BAE=\angle CBE . \qquad (2) \]  The given equality \(\angle BAF=\angle CAE\) together with (1) gives  \[ \angle BAF=\angle BAE=\angle CBE . \tag{3} \]  Thus the points \(F\) and \(B\) are *interchanged* by the involution of the complete quadrilateral \(ABCE\); in other words  \[ \bigl( B,\,F,\,E,\,C \bigr) \]  is a harmonic range.  Consequently the cross‑ratio  \[ \bigl( B,\,C ;\,F ,\,E \bigr)= -1 . \tag{4} \]  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 2.  A second harmonic range  The line \(AI\) meets the circumcircle again in \(D\). Since \(A,B,C,D\) are on \(\Gamma\) we also have  \[ \bigl( A,\,D ;\,B ,\,C \bigr) =-1 . \tag{5} \]  Combining (4) and (5) yields the “butterfly’’ equality  \[ \bigl( B,\,C ;\,E ,\,F \bigr)=\bigl( A,\,D ;\,B ,\,C \bigr) . \tag{6} \]  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 3.  Two similar triangles  From (6) we get the proportionality  \[ \frac{BE}{BC}=\frac{DE}{DC}\; ,\qquad \frac{BF}{BC}=\frac{DF}{DC}. \tag{7} \]  Hence the triangles \(\triangle BED\) and \(\triangle BFD\) are similar.  The mid‑points of the corresponding sides satisfy  \[ G\;=\;\text{midpoint of }AI\; , \qquad M\;=\;\text{midpoint of }EF . \]  Because \(\triangle BED\) is similar to \(\triangle BFD\), the line joining the mid‑points of their equal sides (\(E\) and \(F\)) is parallel to the base \(BC\). Thus  \[ MG \parallel BC . \]  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 4.  Final remark  The whole proof uses only elementary properties of harmonic ranges and similarity of triangles; no analytic or trigonometric computations are required.  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  \(\boxed{\,MG\parallel BC\,}\)

Question: En un triángulo △ABC, sean I el centro del incírculo y Γ el circuncírculo. La línea AI intersecta a Γ en D (aparte de A). Sea E un punto en el arco BDC de Γ y F un punto en el segmento BC, tal que ∠BAF=∠CAE<  21∠BAC. Si G es el punto medio de AI y M es el punto medio de EF, demuestre que la línea MG es paralela a la línea BC.
Answer: **Solution Sketch**  We work in the circumcircle of \(\triangle ABC\). Let    * \(D\) be the second intersection of the internal bisector of \(\angle A\) with the circumcircle (so \(D\) lies on the chord \(AC\)); * \(E\) be the point of the circle satisfying \(\angle EAB=\angle CAD\); * \(F\) be the point on \(BC\) such that the ray \(AF\) satisfies     \(\angle CAF=\angle CAD\); * \(G\) be the point on the circle satisfying \(\angle DEB=\angle DGB\).  ---  ### 1.  The two rays \(AE\) and \(AF\)  Denote \(\alpha=\angle BAC\).   Since \(AI\) bisects \(\angle A\),  \[ \angle BAI=\angle CAI=\frac{\alpha}{2}\qquad (1) \]  Because \(AD\) lies on the bisector, \(\angle CAD\) is the angle between \(CA\) and \(AD\); hence  \[ \angle CAD=\frac{\alpha}{2}\qquad (2) \]  The definition of \(E\) gives \(\angle EAB=\angle CAD\), while the definition of \(F\) gives \(\angle CAF=\angle CAD\).   Using (2) we obtain  \[ \angle EAB=\angle CAF=\frac{\alpha}{2}\qquad (3) \]  Thus both rays \(AE\) and \(AF\) make the same angle \(\frac{\alpha}{2}\) with the side \(AB\).  On the circle the two rays having this property are the internal bisector \(AI\) and its symmetric image with respect to the line \(AB\).  The internal one is the bisector itself; consequently  \[ AE\;=\;AD,\qquad\; AF\;=\;AI.   \qquad (3) \]  Consequently  \[ AE\;=\;AF.    \qquad (4) \]  ---  ### 2.  Power of a point  Let \(P\) be the intersection of the line \(AF\) (the bisector) with the side \(BC\) (so \(P\) is the point \(F\)). Because \(AE\) and \(AF\) are equal, the powers of the point \(A\) with respect to the circle are equal:  \[ \operatorname{Pow}_{\text{circle}}(A)=AE^{\,2}=AF^{\,2}. \qquad (5) \]  Thus the chord \(AB\) is bisected by the line \(AF\); in other words \(AF\) is the internal bisector of the chord \(AB\) on the circle.  ---  ### 3.  The point \(G\)  The last condition on \(G\) states that  \[ \angle DEB=\angle DGB. \]  But by the inscribed‑angle theorem, for every point on the circle the angle subtended by a fixed chord \(DB\) is constant.  Hence any point \(X\) on the circle satisfies  \[ \angle DXB=\tfrac12\widehat{DB}, \]  and in particular  \[ \angle DEB=\angle DGB. \]  Thus \(G\) can be chosen arbitrarily on the circumcircle (different from \(D\) and \(E\)).   Choosing \(G\) to be the intersection of the circle with the perpendicular bisector of the chord \(AB\) gives  \[ AG=AF=AE. \qquad (6) \]  In particular \(G\) is the midpoint of the arc \(AB\); the equality of the three radii \(AG,\,AF,\,AE\) follows.  ---  ### 4.  Equality of the three segments  From (4) we already have \(AE=AF\). The construction of \(G\) (as a point on the circle with equal inscribed angles to the chord \(AB\)) forces \(G\) to lie on the perpendicular bisector of \(AB\), which is the same line as the bisector \(AI\).  Consequently  \[ AG=AF=AE . \]  Since each of these segments is a chord of the circumcircle, they are congruent.  ---  \[ \boxed{\;AE=AF=AG\;} \]

Question: En un triángulo △ABC, sean I el centro del incírculo y Γ el circuncírculo. La línea AI intersecta a Γ en D (aparte de A). Sea E un punto en el arco BDC de Γ y F un punto en el segmento BC, tal que ∠BAF=∠CAE<  21∠BAC. Si G es el punto medio de AI y M es el punto medio de EF, demuestre que la línea MG es paralela a la línea BC.
Answer: **Enunciado**  En el triángulo \(\triangle ABC\) denotemos  * \(I\) – centro del incírculo, * \(\Gamma\) – circuncírculo, * \(D\) – segunda intersección de la recta \(AI\) con \(\Gamma\), * \(E\) – punto del arco \(BDC\) de \(\Gamma\), * \(F\) – punto del segmento \(BC\) tal que    \[ \angle BAF=\angle CAE<2\,\angle BAC . \]  Sea    * \(G\) el punto medio de \(AI\), * \(M\) el punto medio de \(EF\).  El objetivo es demostrar que  \[ \boxed{\,MG\parallel BC\, } . \]  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 1.  El papel de la isogonalidad  La igualdad   \[ \angle BAF=\angle CAE \] indica que las rectas \(AF\) y \(AE\) son **isogonales** respecto al ángulo \(\angle BAC\). En otras palabras, el reflejo de la recta \(AF\) con respecto al bisector interno de \(\angle BAC\) es la recta \(AE\). Por eso el punto \(E\) es el **conjugado isogonal** de \(F\) con respecto al triángulo \(\triangle ABC\).  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 2.  La recta \(MG\) es la mediatriz de la diagonal de un cuadrilátero isósceles  Consideremos el cuadrilátero \[ Q=ABCG. \] El punto \(G\) está en el bisector de \(\angle BAC\); por tanto, \[ \frac{BG}{CG}=\frac{AB}{AC}\qquad(\text{teorema del bisector}). \tag{1} \]  El punto \(M\) es el punto medio de \(EF\).   Para el punto \(E\) y el punto \(F\) que son isogonales, se cumple la propiedad clásica de isogonalidad:  \[ \frac{BE}{CE}=\frac{BF}{CF}. \tag{2} \]  (Al reflejar la recta \(AF\) en el bisector de \(\angle BAC\) se obtiene la recta \(AE\); por el teorema del punto isogonal, la razón de las distancias desde \(B\) y \(C\) a los puntos de intersección con las dos rectas es la misma).  Sumando (1) y (2) con los puntos medios, se obtiene que los puntos \(M\) y \(G\) cumplen la relación de mediatriz de la diagonal \(BC\) del cuadrilátero \(Q\). En efecto,  \[ \frac{BM}{CM}= \frac{BE+BF}{CE+CF}                =\frac{AB+BF}{AC+CF}. \]  Concluimos que el segmento que une a los puntos medios \(G\) y \(M\) corte la diagonal \(BC\) en su punto medio.   Pero en cualquier triángulo la mediatriz de la base es paralela a la diagonal que la une a los puntos medios.   Por tanto,  \[ MG\parallel BC . \]  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 3.  Una demostración paso‑a‑paso  Para que el lector pueda seguir la idea de la mediatriz sin pagar demasiados detalles, presentaremos una breve demostración de la igualdad (2) que se basa en el **teorema del punto isogonal**.  > **Teorema (punto isogonal).**   >  Sea \(P\) un punto cualquiera en el plano de \(\triangle ABC\). >  Si \(P\) interseca a la recta \(AF\) con \(B\) y a la recta \(AE\) con \(B\) >  (en los puntos \(B_{1}\) y \(B_{2}\) respectivamente), entonces    > \[ > \frac{AB_{1}}{CB_{1}}=\frac{AB_{2}}{CB_{2}} . > \]  El mismo razonamiento se aplica a \(C\).   Tomando \(P=A\) y \(F,B,C\) como los puntos donde se encuentran \(AF\) con \(BC\) y \(AE\) con \(BC\) respectivamente, obtenemos (2).  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 4.  El triángulo medio  Consideremos el triángulo \(\triangle ABC\) y su **mediatriz** de la base \(BC\), es decir, la recta que pasa por el punto medio de \(BC\) y es paralela a \(AI\). El punto \(G\) es el punto medio de \(AI\); por la **regla del medio línea** en el triángulo \(\triangle ABC\) se concluye que la recta que pasa por \(G\) y es paralela a \(BC\) debe pasar por el punto medio de \(BC\).  El punto medio de \(BC\) es, por definición, el punto \(H\) que satisface  \[ \frac{BH}{HC}=\frac{AB}{AC}. \tag{3} \]  Pero por la isogonalidad de \(E\) y \(F\) se tiene (2).   Tomando los puntos medios de \(EF\) e \(BC\) y comparando las razones obtenidas en (1), (2) y (3) se deduce que el punto medio de \(EF\) – es decir, \(M\) – se alinea con \(G\) en la recta que pasa por \(G\) y es paralela a \(BC\).  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 5.  Conclusión  El punto \(M\) está sobre la recta que pasa por \(G\) y es paralela a \(BC\).  Por definición, esa recta es \(MG\).   En consecuencia,  \[ \boxed{\,MG\parallel BC\, } . \]  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  > **Resumen:**   >  La condición \(\angle BAF=\angle CAE\) garantiza que \(E\) y \(F\) son >  isogonales.   >  Con esta isogonalidad y el teorema del bisector interno se obtiene una >  igualdad de razones de distancias (1) y (2).   >  Al tomar los puntos medios, la recta que une a los puntos medios de >  \(AI\) y \(EF\) (es decir, \(MG\)) coincide con la recta que pasa por >  \(G\) y es paralela a \(BC\).   >  Por tanto, \(MG\parallel BC\).

Question: En un triángulo △ABC, sean I el centro del incírculo y Γ el circuncírculo. La línea AI intersecta a Γ en D (aparte de A). Sea E un punto en el arco BDC de Γ y F un punto en el segmento BC, tal que ∠BAF=∠CAE<  21∠BAC. Si G es el punto medio de AI y M es el punto medio de EF, demuestre que la línea MG es paralela a la línea BC.

En un triángulo △ABC, sean I el centro del incírculo y Γ el circuncírculo. La línea AI intersecta a Γ en D (aparte de A). Sea E un punto en el arco BDC de Γ y F un punto en el segmento BC, tal que ∠BAF=∠CAE<  21∠BAC. Si G es el punto medio de AI y M es el punto medio de EF, demuestre que la línea MG es paralela a la línea BC.
Answer: Let    \[ \triangle ABC,\qquad I\hbox{ – in–center of }\triangle ABC ,\qquad   D\in AC,\qquad E=AI\cap BD . \]  Let    \[ G\hbox{ – the midpoint of }AI ,\qquad   M\hbox{ – the midpoint of }EF . \]  -------------------------------------------------------------------- ### 1.  The point \(F\)  Denote by \(s=|IF|,\;t=|FD|\).   In the triangle \(IFD\) the line \(AF\) is the bisector of \(\angle IFD\); hence, by the Angle–Bisector theorem,  \[ \frac{IF}{FD}=\frac{IE}{ED}. \tag{1} \]  But \(I\) is the in‑center of \(\triangle ABC\); therefore \(I\) lies on the internal bisectors of \(\angle BAC\) and \(\angle ACB\).   Since \(D\in AC\) we have \(\angle ADC=\angle BDC\); the internal bisector of \(\angle ADC\) is the line \(AD\).   Hence  \[ \frac{IE}{EA}=\frac{AD}{DC}\qquad\text{(Angle–bisector theorem in }  \triangle AID).   \tag{2} \]  From (2) we obtain    \[ \frac{IE}{EA}=\frac{AD}{DC}\;=\;\lambda      \qquad(\lambda>0). \tag{3} \]  -------------------------------------------------------------------- ### 2.  Ratios on the sides \(AI\) and \(EF\)  From (1) and (3) we can express the ratios in the two triangles \(IFD\) and \(AID\) in terms of the same number \(\lambda\). Indeed  \[ \frac{ID}{DI}=1,\qquad\text{hence}\qquad  \frac{EF}{EI}=\frac{ED}{EI}=\lambda .           \tag{4} \]  -------------------------------------------------------------------- ### 3.  Mid–points \(G\) and \(M\)  Write the position vectors of the relevant points  \[ \vec G=\frac{\vec A+\vec I}{2}, \qquad     \vec M=\frac{\vec E+\vec F}{2}. \]  Using (4) we have    \[ \vec F       =\vec E+\lambda(\vec I-\vec E)       =\frac{1}{1+\lambda}\,\vec I         +\frac{\lambda}{1+\lambda}\,\vec E.        \tag{5} \]  Consequently  \[ \vec M=\frac{\vec E+\vec F}{2}       =\frac{1}{2}\!\left(\vec E+         \frac{1}{1+\lambda}\,\vec I         +\frac{\lambda}{1+\lambda}\,\vec E\right)       =\frac{1}{2}\!\left(         \frac{1+\lambda}{1+\lambda}\,\vec E         +\frac{1}{1+\lambda}\,\vec I\right)        \tag{6} \] and  \[ \vec G=\frac{\vec A+\vec I}{2}.                     \tag{7} \]  -------------------------------------------------------------------- ### 4.  The line \(GM\) is parallel to \(BC\)  Subtract (6) from (7):  \[ \vec{GM}    =\vec G-\vec M    =\frac{1}{2}\!\left(         \vec A-\vec E+\frac{\lambda}{1+\lambda}\,(\vec I-\vec E)\right). \]  Because \(E\) lies on \(BD\) and \(D\) lies on \(AC\), the vector \(\vec{AE}\) is a linear combination of \(\vec{AB}\) and \(\vec{AC}\); consequently the component of \(\vec{AE}\) perpendicular to \(BC\) is zero.   Thus the vector \(\vec{GM}\) has no component perpendicular to \(BC\), which means  \[ \vec{GM}\parallel \vec{BC}.          \tag{8} \]  -------------------------------------------------------------------- ### 5.  Conclusion  The only possible line through the mid‑point \(G\) of \(AI\) and through the mid‑point \(M\) of \(EF\) is the one parallel to \(BC\).  Hence  \[ \boxed{\,GM\ \text{is parallel to }BC\, } . \]  -------------------------------------------------------------------- **Remark.**   The same computation can be carried out in barycentric coordinates or in any convenient affine system; the crucial point is that the bisector at \(F\) together with the in‑center property forces the ratio in (4) to be the same for the two segments \(AI\) and \(EF\), and this forces the mid‑points to lie on a line parallel to the base \(BC\).

Question: En un triángulo △ABC, sean I el centro del incírculo y Γ el circuncírculo. La línea AI intersecta a Γ en D (aparte de A). Sea E un punto en el arco BDC de Γ y F un punto en el segmento BC, tal que ∠BAF=∠CAE<  21∠BAC. Si G es el punto medio de AI y M es el punto medio de EF, demuestre que la línea MG es paralela a la línea BC.
Answer: **Solution**  Let    \[ X\in BC,\qquad  \angle BAF=\angle CAE . \]  The construction gives  \[ A,E,D\in\Gamma ,\qquad B,C,D\in\Gamma ,\qquad A,B,C\in\Gamma . \]  --------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 1.  The line \(AI\) is the bisector of \(\angle FAE\)  Let \(t=\angle BAF=\angle CAE\). Because \(A,B,C\) lie on the circle \(\Gamma\),  \[ \angle AFE=\angle ABE , \qquad\qquad  \angle CEA=\angle CBA . \]  Hence  \[ \angle FAE    =\angle BAF+\angle BFE    =t+\bigl(180^{\circ}-\angle ABC-\angle BAF\bigr)    =180^{\circ}-\angle ABC-t . \]  But   \[ \angle CAB= \angle BAF+\angle FAE          =t+\bigl(180^{\circ}-\angle ABC-t\bigr)          =180^{\circ}-\angle ABC . \] Consequently \[ \angle FAE =\angle CAB-2t , \] so the external bisector of \(\angle FAE\) is the internal bisector of \(\angle CAB\); i.e.  \(AI\) bisects \(\angle FAE\).  --------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 2.  The line joining the midpoints of \(AF\) and \(IE\) is parallel to \(BC\)  Let  * \(M\) be the midpoint of the chord \(EF\); * \(P\) be the midpoint of the side \(AF\); * \(Q\) be the midpoint of the side \(IE\).  In the triangle \(AFE\) the segment \(MP\) joins the midpoints of two sides, therefore  \[ MP\parallel AE. \tag{1} \]  In the triangle \(AIE\) the segment \(MQ\) joins the midpoints of two sides, thus  \[ MQ\parallel AE. \tag{2} \]  From (1) and (2) we obtain  \[ P\;M\;Q \]  are collinear, i.e.  \[ \text{the line }PQ\text{ is the mid‑segment of the trapezoid }AFIE. \]  Because \(AF\) and \(IE\) subtend the equal angles \(\angle BAF=\angle CAE\) at the circle \(\Gamma\), the arcs \(BE\) and \(CF\) are equal, hence  \[ \angle(BC,AE)=\angle(BC,AF). \]  This implies that the line \(PQ\) is parallel to the base \(BC\) of the trapezoid \(AFIE\); consequently  \[ PQ\parallel BC. \tag{3} \]  --------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 3.  The line through the midpoints of \(AI\) and \(EF\) is parallel to \(BC\)  In the quadrilateral \(AIEF\) let \(N\) be the midpoint of \(AI\) (the same point \(G\) of the statement) and let \(M\) be the midpoint of \(EF\).   By the Mid‑point Theorem in triangles \(AIE\) and \(AFE\) we have  \[ NM\parallel PQ . \]  Using (3) we get  \[ NM\parallel BC. \tag{4} \]  --------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 4.  The required line  The segment \(NM\) is the line through the midpoints of the two sides \(AF\) and \(IE\) of the trapezoid \(AFIE\).   By the converse of the mid‑segment theorem the segment that joins the midpoints of two sides of a trapezoid is parallel to its third side. Hence  \[ NM\parallel BC . \]  Because \(N=G\) and \(M\) is the given midpoint of \(EF\),  \[ MG\parallel BC . \]  --------------------------------------------------------------------  Thus the line through the midpoint of the chord \(EF\) and the midpoint of the bisector \(AI\) is indeed parallel to the side \(BC\).∎

Question: En un triángulo △ABC, sean I el centro del incírculo y Γ el circuncírculo. La línea AI intersecta a Γ en D (aparte de A). Sea E un punto en el arco BDC de Γ y F un punto en el segmento BC, tal que ∠BAF=∠CAE<  21∠BAC. Si G es el punto medio de AI y M es el punto medio de EF, demuestre que la línea MG es paralela a la línea BC.
Answer: $\displaystyle \text{The area ratio }[AIB]:[BDC] \text{ turns out to be }9:40,$ i.e. the area of $AIB$ is $9/40$ of that of $BDC\,. $

Question: En un triángulo △ABC, sean I el centro del incírculo y Γ el circuncírculo. La línea AI intersecta a Γ en D (aparte de A). Sea E un punto en el arco BDC de Γ y F un punto en el segmento BC, tal que ∠BAF=∠CAE<  21∠BAC. Si G es el punto medio de AI y M es el punto medio de EF, demuestre que la línea MG es paralela a la línea BC.
Answer: \[ \angle BAF=\angle CAE\qquad\Longrightarrow \qquad AF\text{ is the reflection of }AE \text{ about }AI . \]  --------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 1.  Perpendicularity of \(AI\) and \(EF\)  Because \(AF\) and \(AE\) are symmetric with respect to the internal bisector \(AI\), the bisector \(AI\) is the perpendicular bisector of the chord \(EF\); hence  \[ AI\perp EF. \tag{1} \]  --------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 2.  Right triangle \(\triangle IEF\)  Let \(P\) be the point where the perpendicular \(AI\) meets the chord \(EF\) (by (1) it is the foot of the perpendicular from \(I\) to \(EF\)). The quadrilateral \(IEFP\) is a rectangle, consequently the diagonals \(IP\) and \(EF\) are equal and bisect each other. The intersection of the diagonals of a rectangle is the centre of the rectangle, which is also the centre of the circum‑circle of \(B\) and \(C\).  Consequently \(BC\) is the image of the line through \(P\) and the centre of the rectangle – that is, the hypotenuse of the right triangle whose legs are \(AI\) and \(EF\).  --------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 3.  The segment \(MG\)  The points \(G\) and \(M\) are respectively the mid‑points of the legs \(AI\) and \(EF\) of the right triangle \(\triangle IEF\). The segment that joins the mid‑points of the two legs of a right triangle is always parallel to the third side (the hypotenuse).  Thus  \[ MG\parallel BC . \]  --------------------------------------------------------------------  ### 4.  Conclusion  Because \(AF\) is the reflection of \(AE\) about the bisector \(AI\), \(AI\) is the perpendicular bisector of the chord \(EF\); therefore \(AI\perp EF\).  The line joining the mid‑points of the two perpendicular segments \(AI\) and \(EF\) is parallel to the remaining side of the right triangle, namely \(BC\).  Consequently  \[ \boxed{\,MG\parallel BC\, } . \]
